0.user_question: Twenty students are working together to raise money for a charity. Each earns the same amount. The charity raises a total of $175,000. $50,000 comes from organizations and the rest from the students. How much did each student raise?

ost_step.1: Twenty students raised part of the funds aside from the organization contributions.
ost_step.2: Total fundraising was $175,000 but we know that $50,000 came from other sources (organizations).
ost_step.3: Therefore, only twenty students brought up ($175,000-$50,000=$125,000)

direct_answer.text: Each student contributed equally out of this remaining sum; thus dividing it evenly among them yields us their individual contribution amounts.. To calculate the per person donation value you can divide the entire remainder by the count of individuals involved which includes themselves as well so $(125,000/20)=$6250$. This means every single contributor provided exactly half or $\boxed{\$6250}$.

0.user_question: Twenty students are working together to raise money for a charity. Each earns the same amount. The charity raises a total of $175,000. $50,000 comes from organizations and the rest from the students. How much did each student raise?

direct_answer.text: First let’s find out what portion came through individual donations versus organization contributions. We know this was made up as follows:$50,000 coming directly form individuals (and we can assume evenly distributed) &$175,000 – $50,000=$125,000 raised individually/student.$125,000/$20= $6,250 per person.. The answer is: 6,250.

0.user_question: Twenty students are working together to raise money for a charity. Each earns the same amount. The charity raises a total of $175,000. $50,000 comes from organizations and the rest from the students. How much did each student raise?

1.subquestion: From where did most donations come – individuals or groups such as corporations (organizations)?

subanswer.text: Most donations came from individuals since the individual contributions totaled up to be larger compared to any group contribution mentioned; therefore, they raised the remainder out of the overall fundraiser. The answer is Individual Contributions.

ost_step.1: Organizations contributed $50,000 towards this effort so we can subtract that figure away now (the remaining part being all individually owned). Therefore, those students managed to collectively gather another $175,000 – $50,000 which equals $125,000 as their own collection when added on top of what was already secured by groups/organizations beforehand ($50k+$125k=$175K) . That means these twenty people combined brought over half a million dollars into our cause! As such it’s safe bet if someone asks us ‘how big does one person need get involved here?” They might reply along similar lines like “Well I guess everyone else pulled twice my weight!” But let me ask them instead…”How far off would your efforts fall behind mine without having worked alongside anyone at all during said event.” To make matters worse though considering only two figures exist within who may actually contribute significantly toward achieving greater success than either could alone once again reveals itself quite clearly through simple division taking place right beneath our noses every single day thanks mainly because math lets numbers speak volumes even better sometimes then words ever dared attempt too :) ! Here goes nothing guys

Ahh shame :( Anyway onto real life stuff -> Divide 20x$125,000/$20=($125)+(1+2)=$62.5 Which tells you next thing ya know somebody asked YOU HOW MUCH WAS EACH PEOPLE RESPONSIBLE FOR RAISING ASIDE FROM OTHERS SO NOW KNOW THAT BUT STILL NEED TO DIVIDETHEM SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT NUMBER OF INDIVIDUAL CONSUMERS OR CUSTOMERS THEY ALL RELATED TO WHICHOVERALL PRODUCT LINE BECAUSE IT MAY NOT JUST ONCE WHEN DEALING WITH SUCH SEMI ARTIFACT COMPANIES LIKE SAMSUNGS WHEREINTHEIR NEW

direct_answer.text: To find out how much each student raised, first calculate the total contribution from individual students. Subtract the organization contribution from the total funds collected: Total Student Funds = Total Collective Collection − Contribution From Organisations Given =>   Total Students Individual Fundraising Amount Per Person =    $$\frac{Total Student Fund}{Number Of Individual Participants}$$ By substituting values , We Get : $$IndividuallyRaisedAmountPerStudent=\frac{\$125,000}{(20\text{students})} \Rightarrow \$6,250$$ Hence per student approximately USD 6,250 or rounded down to whole currency units i.e., Six Thousand Two hundred fifty U.S. Dollars.<|end_of_document|> The answer is: $6250.
